tweet: We cannot sit back and allow foreign adversaries to influence our elections.
I'm glad that Davidson County will have voting machines with paper ballots in the upcoming August election, but the majority of counties in our country don't use these types of machines.
National security and intelligence experts agree the U.S. election system is under attack. Paper ballots are one of the most important ways to make our elections more secure.
The SAFE Act will help ensure funding is available for every state to purchase voting equipment with a voter-verified paper audit trail.

This decision is a temporary victory, and it is important that we do not become complacent. We must encourage our families, friends, and neighbors to participate in the census so their voices can be adequately represented in Congress.
Adding a question about citizenship to the 2020 Census is a blatant effort to marginalize members of our communities.
While I’m glad the Supreme Court did not allow the addition of the citizenship question to go forward today, I’m worried that Secretary Ross will continue to try and add it in the future.

The Supreme Court’s gerrymandering decision is shortsighted and dangerous for our country. Now it’s up to Congress to fix the system by passing my redistricting reform bills. Voters ought to be able to pick their politicians, not the other way around. https://bit.ly/2ZUmLJ3

Today we commemorate #Juneteenth, the end of slavery in the U.S. The Emancipation Proclamation was signed into law on January 1, 1863, but about 250,000 individuals remained enslaved in Texas until June 19, 1865, almost 2.5 years after Lincoln’s proclamation.

Today we commemorate the brave soldiers, including more than 300,000 Tennesseans, who served in WWII. Our state played a unique role in the war through the Tennessee Maneuver Area - training locations in Middle TN with terrain that resembled France, Belgium and Germany.

According to @amprog, DREAMers and immigrants with TPS and DED status in Cheatham, Davidson and Dickson counties spend more than $200 million annually and pay more than $63 million in federal, state and local taxes.

Many of these residents are students and have lived in our state for years. They have become vital members of the community. They are going to school, working and serving in our military. They also make significant contributions to our economy.
Now that the House has passed the American Dream and Promise Act, the Senate needs to put politics aside and do what’s right for Tennessee and for our country.
